summaries.novice: Learn the foundations of the 3-term contingency and basic ABA concepts.
summaries.standard: Analyze antecedents, consequences, and behavior function.
summaries.expert: Apply ABC analysis to real-world scenarios using function-based logic.

novice.title: Overview of ABC
content: Applied Behavior Analysis uses the Antecedent–Behavior–Consequence model.
Behavior is influenced by what happens before and after it.

novice.title: Antecedents & Stimulus Control
content: Antecedents occur before behavior.
Stimulus control exists when behavior occurs in the presence of an SD.

novice.title: Defining Behavior
content: Behavior must be observable, measurable, and objective.
Avoid emotional or subjective language.

novice.title: Consequences
content: Consequences follow behavior.
They affect the future likelihood of behavior.

novice.title: Functions of Behavior
content: Escape
Attention
Access to tangibles
Sensory stimulation

novice.title: Putting It All Together
content: Analyze antecedents and consequences together.
Use patterns to determine function.

standard.title: Objective vs Subjective Definitions
content: Objective definitions describe observable, measurable actions.
They avoid mentalistic or emotional language.
Subjective definitions rely on personal interpretation or inference.
Behavior plans require objective definitions to ensure consistency.
Two people should be able to observe the same behavior and agree.

standard.title: Components of the 3-Term Contingency
content: Antecedent occurs before the behavior.
Behavior is observable and measurable.
Consequence follows the behavior.
Changing any component can affect responding.
This model is foundational to all ABA programs.

standard.title: Examples vs Non-Examples of Behavior
content: Behaviors must be directly observable.
Thoughts and feelings are not behaviors.
Smiling, hitting, and running are behaviors.
Wanting, thinking, or remembering are not behaviors.
Correct identification improves data accuracy.

expert.title: Function vs Topography
content: Topography describes the form of a behavior.
Function explains why the behavior occurs.
Different behaviors can serve the same function.
The same behavior can serve different functions.
Treatment focuses on function, not appearance.

expert.title: Predicting Behavior Change Using ABC
content: Altering antecedents can prevent problem behavior.
Changing consequences can increase or decrease behavior.
Motivating operations influence behavior value.
Patterns emerge when ABC data is analyzed.
Effective intervention is proactive, not reactive.

expert.title: Behavioral Precision and Clinical Impact
content: Clear definitions support reliable data collection.
Poor definitions lead to inconsistent implementation.
Precision improves interobserver agreement.
High-quality data enables ethical decision-making.
This skill separates technicians from tacticians.
